Forest of snakes
 Joseph Sanchez Nadimo
 English 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Sinyaire vilage is surounded by hils.
 
 
 Many snakes live in the forest on those
 hils. 
 
 
 The bigest snake was caled Unyalego
 by the vilagers. 
 
 
 This snake scared many people. 
 
 It swalowed whole goats and shep.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 One day, sisters Apiyo, Ajoh and
 
 Atieno were going to the forest to fetch
 firewod. 
 
 
 The girls’ grandmother warned, 
 “Beware of Unyalego the big snake.
 
 Do not take anything from the forest
 except the wod.” 
 
 
 Only Ajoh did not pay atention to her
 grandmother. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 2  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The girls packed milk, bananas, 
 swet potatoes and water. 
 
 
 They tok ropes for tying firewod
 and a sharp machete for choping
 the wod. 
 
 
 Then they left for the forest. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 3  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 On the way, the sisters chated 
 and laughed. 
 
 
 Sudenly, Apiyo, the eldest of them, said,
 “Be quiet. We are 
 
 coming to where Unyalego lives.”
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 4  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Atieno caled to the others, “Lok, here
 are Unyalego’s golden teth. Let us take
 them.” 
 
 
 Apiyo reminded them, “Don't forget
 grandmother’s warning. We must not
 
 take anything from the forest except
 firewod.” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 5  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Ajoh said, “I don't trust grandmother. I
 think she said that to stop us having
 what we want. I want the golden teth.”
 
 
 Her sisters were woried. “Ajoh, we
 warned you,” they said. 
 
 
 Ajoh did not care. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 6  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 At that moment Unyalego came 
 loking for his golden teth. He was
 
 furious when he could not find the
 teth. 
 
 
 Then Unyalego heard the girls 
 chating and laughing. He hid under
 
 a rock next to the road where the
 girls would pas on their way back.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 7  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 The sisters were going home carying
 their firewod on their heads. 
 
 
 Sudenly, they heard “Hz!” There
 was Unyalego with his mouth 
 wide open, ready to bite. The girls
 
 were terified. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 8  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Unyalego asked the girls, “Who 
 
 tok my golden teth?” No one 
 answered. 
 
 
 The snake decided to test the girls.
 “Whoever is inocent, wil be able
 
 to sing without mistakes. She wil
 go home with her firewod. 
 
 But the guilty one wil sing badly.
 She wil be my fod for the next
 thre days!” 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 9  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Apiyo started to sing with a clear
 voice: 
 
 
 “Sio mimi, sio mimi aliye na meno,
 Mwenye meno bado yuko nyuma.” 
 
 
 Then Atieno sang the song. She also
 sang wel. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 10  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Lastly, it was Ajoh’s turn. She was
 
 scared. She steped forward and 
 started singing. But her singing
 
 sounded terible and the words 
 were wrong. 
 
 
 Unyalego shouted, “Can’t you sing
 properly like the others?” 
 
 
 The snake knew that Ajoh tok his
 golden teth. 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 1  
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 Unyalego opened his huge jaws and
 swalowed Ajoh. 
 
 
 Her sisters ran back to the vilage.
 They told everyone the story of what
 
 hapened. 
 
 
 “I warned her, if only she had listened,”
 the girls' grandmother said sadly.
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 
 12
